journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Achievement of a uniform contact pressure in a shaft–hub press-fit

contrib-group.aff: Enzo Ferrari Department of Engineering, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, Italy

author-notes.corresp: A Strozzi, Enzo Ferrari Department of Engineering, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, via Vignolese 905, 41126 Modena, Italy. Email: antonio.strozzi@unimore.it

abstract.p: In this article, the achievement of a uniform elastic contact pressure in a frictionless, keyless, shaft–hub interference fit obtained by properly shaping the mating profiles is examined. The peculiarity of the hub mechanical response according to which, under the effect of a uniform pressure applied to the hub bore, the bore axial profile moves radially without any distortion, is exploited to simplify the determination of the mating profiles that return a uniform pressure. In particular, the hub radial deflection may be computed with a simple plane model, whereas only the shaft radial deflection requires a more complex analysis in cylindrical coordinates. Explicit approximate expressions are reported for the shapes to be conferred to the mating profiles to achieve a uniform pressure. Selected examples are presented to clarify the proposed design procedure and to preliminarily explore the effect on the pressure profile of simple shape errors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The current years witness the recent explosion in new machining technology, not only CNC (computer numerical control) machines, but the more widespread use of multi-axis control. These new technologies have allowed continuous improvements in the finely toleranced manufacturing of the contacting profiles between mechanical components, and they have spurred the adoption of shapes of the contacting zones that can promote favourable stress distributions. Some representative examples extracted from the precision mechanics realm are perfunctorily described in what follows.

With regard to the roller bearing field, the studies of Lundberg on the correction to be imparted to the axial profile of the roller extremities to achieve a uniform contact pressure in the roller axial direction are reported in Johnson1 (p. 134). In Heydari and Gohar,2 the reduction in the diameter of the roller extremities to spread the contact pressure evenly is found to be of the order of 1/1000th of the roller centre diameter.

In high-performance engines, the inner surface of the small-end bush is generally inverse barrelled, where the barrelling serves to accommodate for the pin bending and, consequently, to limit the untoward pressure peaks at the contact extremities.3 For a commonplace 20 mm diameter steel pin, the barrelling of the bush profile is described in terms of an arc of a circle whose radius is about 30 times the pin diameter.

In high-tech pistons, pin bosses are adopted whose pin bores exhibit a diameter (partially) varying along the bore axis.4 In particular, a boss splayed seat, whose diameter increases towards the small-end lateral faces, is frequently employed to achieve a pin–hub contact pressure that stays more uniform in the pin axial direction. The splayed portion of the boss bore is generally limited to the zone closer to the small-end lateral faces; its axial length is about one-fourth of the pin diameter, and, for a 20 mm diameter pin, the increase in the bore diameter is about 30 µm, with a fine tolerance range smaller than 10 µm. The splayed profile is supplied to the CNC by reporting the coordinates of a series of subsequent points, whose axial step is in the region of 1 mm. In race applications, a non-axisymmetric splayed profile is sometimes adopted to account for the differences in intensity of the load pulling and pushing the conrod shank and the consequent differences in the pin bending. In such high-tech applications, a detailed knowledge of the temperature distribution in working conditions is required.
Finally, modifications of gear tooth profiles to limit vibration and noise have been proposed in Bonori et al.5

This article focuses upon the elastic contact pressure distribution in a frictionless, keyless, shaft–hub press-fit; the shape of the contacting profiles that promotes the outcome of a uniform contact pressure is mathematically determined.

The available salient information on the contact stresses in a shaft–hub press-fit may be summarized as follows (see Strozzi et al.6 and the reported literature review). When a cylindrical shaft of infinite length is press-fitted into a keyless cylindrical hub of finite axial length, stress concentrations take place at the shaft–hub contact extremities, whereas the contact stresses remain reasonably constant along the central portion of the contact. If the edges of the hub bore are sharp, infinite elastic pressure peaks occur at the contact extremities. Conversely, when the edges are rounded, pressure lateral bumps of finite intensity take place, and the contact pressure becomes null at the contact extremities; the Hertzian-type lateral bumps and the central flattish zone confer a camel-backed profile to the contact pressure distribution.

In Strozzi et al.,6 diagrams are presented for the prompt determination of the intensity of the stress lateral bumps, which mainly depend upon the radius adopted for the hub bore fillet. Within the range of the fillet radii explored in Strozzi et al.,6 the minimum value of the stress peak is about 2.5 times the central pressure. It may be concluded that the fillet radii considered in Strozzi et al.6 do not allow a constant pressure to be obtained, and, therefore, a specific investigation is needed to determine the shape to be conferred to the contacting profiles that return a uniform contact pressure.

The shape optimization of the contacting profiles has been the subject of a conspicuous number of studies, a representative paper based upon optimization procedures being the reference.7 In some works, the shaft–hub press-fit problem has expressly been considered, e.g. Parsons and Wilson,8 Oda et al.9 and Pedersen,10 and the shape of the contacting profiles returning a uniform pressure has been determined for specific geometries and interferences. For the limit case of a thin-walled cylinder subjected to a band of pressure, an analytical treatment is reported in Singh.11

The main aim of this article is to derive manageable mathematical expressions of the above-optimized profiles that are practically useful in designing a press-fit exhibiting a uniform contact pressure. To this aim, it was found to be more convenient to not adopt a mathematically oriented optimization strategy of ample applicability, as in Klarbring and Haslinger,7 but to exploit the peculiarities of the mechanical response of the specific problem of the shaft–hub contact, which are examined in the following section.

It is finally noted that the achievement of a constant contact pressure removes the lateral pressure bumps that normally affect a press-fit, and, therefore, it limits the undesired outcome of yielding, e.g. Strozzi et al.6 Consequently, the elastically transmissible torque attains its maximum value. However, if fretting fatigue, possibly promoted by shaft bending, affects the press-fit, the constant pressure profile may no longer constitute the optimal design, since the presence of sharp edges of the hub bore limits the occurrence of relative slips and, consequently, it appears to preclude the onset of fretting fatigue.12,13

sec.title: Peculiarities of the mechanical response of the shaft–hub contact
sec.p: In this section, the mechanical response is examined of (a) an infinitely long shaft loaded by a band of uniform pressure and (b) a hub loaded along the whole axial length of its bore by a uniform pressure.

Starting from the point (a), a cylindrical, possibly hollow, infinitely long shaft is assumed to be loaded by a band of uniform pressure. The band length equals the axial length of the hub, and it is supposed to be sufficiently long, so that the asymptotic radial deflection corresponding to a plane stress model is approached in the central part of the loaded portion, where the shaft shrinks uniformly, i.e. between the points C and D in Figure 1. (The critical value of the above band length is quantified in ‘Radial deflection of the shaft surface’ section. The assumption of a sufficiently long hub is removed in ‘Hubs of limited axial length’.) Figure 1.
The radial deflection of shaft and hub.

In addition, the shaft remains virtually undistorted in the regions far away from the loaded portion. The radial deflection of the shaft surface comprised between the above two regions constitutes a transition zone, defined by A and C in Figure 1. B denotes the extremity of the applied pressure band. The curve of the radial deflection of the shaft surface is skew-symmetric with respect to the point B.

The mechanical problem of a cylindrical, possibly hollow, shaft, loaded by a band of uniform pressure, and, in particular, the determination of the surface radial deflection between the points A and C of Figure 1, possesses a distinguished literature, in which the axisymmetric stress–strain field of the cylinder is frequently modelled in terms of a series involving Bessel functions, e.g. Barton,14 Rankin15 and Timoshenko and Goodier.16 Having in mind CNC and multi-axis control-oriented profile descriptions, series expressions involving Bessel functions are practically unsuitable; in this article, approximate but highly accurate and manageable expressions are presented for the corrections to be imparted to the contacting profiles to get a uniform contact pressure.

Moving to the point (b), the hub is described in terms of a hollow cylinder of rectangular cross section and of finite length, loaded at its bore by a uniform pressure. When the hub is uniformly pressurized, the axial profile of its bore expands radially, remaining straight (Figure 1). This property does not appear to have been exploited in the technical literature addressing press-fitted couplings, and it constitutes the key point of this article. If the inner border of the undeformed hub is no longer straight, but moderately shaped (the deviations from the rectangular shape falling within the tolerance field without altering its nominal dimensions), the above property will hold in a slightly approximate fashion, and the inner border will move radially, essentially conserving its shape (Figure 1). (The numerical examples of ‘Selected examples’ section confirm the validity of this approximation.)

It is noted that the above property is valid for any hub aspect ratio rc/ro, where rc and ro are the hub inner and outer radii, respectively (rc nominally coincides with the shaft outer radius; the index c stands for ‘contact’). Contrary to the evaluation of the radial deflection of a shaft loaded by a band of pressure, the deflection of a hub loaded along its bore by a uniform pressure does not require any solution in cylindrical coordinates, since it remains axially constant and, therefore, it may be computed with a considerably simpler plane (polar) model.

The properties examined at the points (a) and (b) suggest the following approach to achieve a uniform contact pressure in a shaft–hub press-fit. The deformed shape of the shaft surface (in particular, the portion B–C of Figure 1) is evaluated for a general uniform pressure p and for general shaft inner, ri, and outer, rc, radii; this profile comprised between B and C is attributed to the hub undeformed bore border (the central part of the hub bore remains cylindrical); under the effect of a uniform pressure p, the hub bore will expand radially, conserving its initial axial profile; the deformed shape of the shaft and the hub is the same, and, therefore, the established contact pressure is uniform.
(It is noted that it is more convenient to shape the hub bore and not the shaft, so that the axial position of the hub with respect to the perfectly cylindrical shaft is not influential.)

The shape conferred to the hub bore produces a uniform contact pressure only for a prescribed interference. This interference may be computed as the sum of the uniform radial expansion of the bore border and of the radial contraction of the central part of the shaft surface, comprised between C and D in Figure 1. Although the plane stress expression of the connection between the contact pressure and the interference is well documented, it is reported here for the reader’s convenience (1)p=EhI2rc1rc2(1-ν)+ro2(1+ν)ro2-rc2+EhEsri2(1+ν)+rc2(1-ν)rc2-ri2 Formula (1) quantifies the link between the contact pressure p, the diametral interference I, the inner, ri, and outer, rc, shaft radii, and the inner, rc, and outer, ro, hub radii (it is recalled that the shaft outer radius nominally coincides with the hub inner radius). In addition, Es and Eh denote the Young’s moduli of the shaft and the hub, respectively, whereas υ is the Poisson’s ratio, which is assumed to be the same for the shaft and the hub materials. In the design procedure favoured in this article, formula (1) is the only mathematical passage in which the hub outer radius, ro, and the Young’s modulus of the hub material, Eh, intervene.

In summary, the following design strategy is proposed. First, starting from the imposed value of the torque T to be transmitted, for a prescribed nominal geometry of the shaft and the hub, and for an estimated value of the coefficient of friction f, the intensity of the uniform elastic contact pressure p is computed with the classical formula (2)T=2πfprc2l where l is the hub axial length.

The diametral interference corresponding to the contact pressure p computed from formula (2) is evaluated from formula (1). The modification to be imparted to the hub bore profile to get a uniform contact pressure is derived from the evaluation of the surface deflection of the shaft subjected to a band of uniform pressure, and it is independent of both the hub aspect ratio, rc/ro, and of the Young’s modulus, Eh, of the hub material, whose effects have already been accounted for in formula (1). It may be concluded that if an analytical expression is available of the shaft surface radial deflection under the effect of a band of uniform pressure and for a specific value of the hollow shaft aspect ratio ri/rc, the contact pressure may be made uniform for any value of the hub aspect ratio rc/ro and of the Young’s modulus of the hub material, Eh.

The effect of the displacements of the contacting profiles in the direction perpendicular to the contact, i.e. in the shaft axis direction is discussed in a qualitative fashion with the aid of Figure 2. In Figure 2(a), the shaft deformed profile between the points B and C (the axial deformation is accounted for), subjected to a band of uniform pressure p, is conferred to the deformed hub, see the hub bore curve between the points B and C in Figure 2(a), and the two contacting profiles match perfectly in the deformed situation. When the hub is unloaded, it elongates axially, so that the axial distance between the points B′ and C′ of Figure 2(b), referring to the undeformed hub, is higher than its axially deformed counterpart between the points B and C of the hub in Figure 2(a). The curve between the points B′ and C′ (and not between the points B and C) is therefore the profile that should be conferred to the undeformed hub to get a perfectly uniform contact pressure p. Figure 2.
The effect of the axial deformation of shaft and hub.

Figure 2(c) illustrates an approximate, simplified approach, favoured in this article, in which the axial displacements are neglected. The shaft deformed profile between the points B′ and C′ is evaluated by ignoring the shaft axial deformation (the shaft material may be idealized as orthotropic with a null Poisson’s ratio in the axial direction), and this curve is conferred to the undeformed hub profile, between the points B′ and C′ of Figure 2(d). Figure 2(e) and (f) depicts the mechanical response during the press-fit of the hub shaped according to Figure 2(d). As a result of the fit, the hub shrinks axially, so that the axial distance between the points B″ and C″ of the hub of Figure 2(f) diminishes with respect to its unfitted counterpart between the points B′ and C′ of the hub in Figure 2(e), and it becomes perceivably shorter than that between the two corresponding points B″' and C″' of the shaft surface deformed by a uniform pressure band (Figure 2(f)). As a result of the above approximation, consisting in neglecting the shaft axial displacement in the evaluation of the profile to be conferred to the undeformed hub bore, the two mating deformed profiles of the shaft and the hub do no longer match perfectly (Figure 2(f)), where this mismatch is a function of the Poisson’s ratio of the materials employed for the shaft and the hub. However, fortunately, this mismatch acts in a way that precludes any undesired indentation of the hub bore edge into the shaft. Consequently, no pressure spikes occur, but a pressure profile becoming null at the shaft–hub contact extremities is expected to take place instead of a perfectly constant pressure distribution (Figure 4). Figure 4.
The pressure profile for the first example.
In the following section, the determination of the radial deflection of the shaft surface is addressed.

sec.title: Radial deflection of the shaft surface
sec.p: In the previous section it has been argued that a shaft–hub constant contact pressure may be achieved by attributing to the undeformed axial profile of the hub bore the deformed profile of the shaft. Consequently, the correct determination of the deformation of a shaft loaded by a band of uniform pressure of finite length constitutes a fundamental step in the approach favoured in this article. In this section, the axial shape of an elastically deformed shaft under the effect of a discontinuous pressure profile is specifically addressed.

Instead of referring to a band of pressure of finite length shown in Figure 1, it seems more convenient to consider the closely related reference loading formed by two adjacent bands of uniform pressure ±p/2 (see Figure 9 of Barton14; the pressure jump is p), for which the loading and, therefore, the radial deflection, are skew-symmetric, see the inset of Figure 3. The corresponding displacement curve coincides with that obtained by imposing a similar pressure profile, but where the intensity of a pressure band is zero, whereas the intensity of the other band is p, (this pressure profile is a Heaviside function), apart from a constant translation u0 expressed by formula (3), obtained for a plane stress modelling in which the imposed pressure is p/2. The surface radial deflection u is a 90° rotated, S-shaped curve (Figure 1), and it ranges between two opposite asymptotic values whose absolute value is expressed by formula (3). (3)u0=prc2Es(ri2+rc2rc2-ri2-ν) Figure 3.
The normalized radial deflection of the shaft surface for a discontinuous pressure profile for ri/rc = 0, 0.4 and 0.8.

In expression (3), Es denotes the Young’s modulus of the shaft and ri and rc the shaft inner and outer radii, respectively. (For ri → 0, formula (3) describes the surface radial deflection of both (a) a cylinder with an unpressurized infinitesimal bore and (b) a solid cylinder.)

With reference to the inset of Figure 3, because of the skew-symmetric loading, the central radial deflection, i.e. where the two pressure bands join together, is zero. In addition, the radial displacement u approaches the corresponding asymptotic value (3) at an axial distance of about 1.5 times the shaft radius (see Figure 18 of Barton14 and Figure 16 of Rankin15).

Although the problem of a cylinder subjected to an axisymmetric Heaviside pressure profile has been the subject of a conspicuous number of papers, a selection of which has been commented throughout this article, the authors are unaware of the availability of manageable expressions of ample validity describing the radial deflection of the cylindrical surface in the neighbourhood of the pressure discontinuity.

sec.title: The Barton series solution reconsidered
sec.p: To fill the above practical gap, following Barton,14 the problem of a solid shaft loaded by two adjacent, infinitely long, pressure bands of opposite sign and of value ±p/2, has been modelled as fictitiously periodic (the imposed period is eight times the shaft outer radius), and trigonometric series expressions for the cylinder stress and strain fields have been obtained. In addition, the solution of Barton,14 valid for solid cylinders, has been extended to hollow cylinders. A perfunctory description of the approach employed is presented hereinafter.

Following Barton14 and Rankin,15 the trigonometric series expansion of the stress function Φ for this skew-symmetric problem with respect to z is (4)Φ=∑n=0∞[anI0(kr)+bnkrI1(kr)+cnK0(kr) +dnkrK1(kr)]cos(kz) where I and K denote Bessel functions of the first and second kind, respectively, and k = πn/(4rc), where rc denotes the shaft outer radius.

If the shaft is solid, only the two Bessel functions of the first kind must be considered.15 In this case, it is convenient to adopt the following formulation of the stress function,16 since the shear stress is null at the shaft surface, r = rc, and the radial and hoop stresses coincide for r = 0: (5)Φ=∑n=0∞an{[2(1-ν)+krcI0(krc)I1(krc)] ×I0(kr)-krI1(kr)}cos(kz) Following again Timoshenko and Goodier,16 the series expression of the radial stress σr is (6)σr=-∑n=0∞an{[-1-krcI0(krc)I1(krc)]I0(kr) +{kr+1kr[2(1-ν)+krcI0(krc)I1(krc)]} ×I1(kr)}k3sin(kz) At the shaft surface, r = rc, and the radial stress becomes (7)σr(rc)=-∑n=0∞an{-krcI02(krc)I1(krc)+{krc+2(1-ν)krc} ×I1(krc)}k3sin(kz) By equating the above expression to the (opposite of the) Fourier series expansion of the fictitiously periodic, discontinuous pressure profile,14 the following explicit analytical expression of the series coefficient an is obtained (8)an={0n even2pπnk31{-krcI02(krc)I1(krc)+{krc+2(1-ν)krc}I1(krc)} nodd Formulae (5) and (8) provide the explicit expression of the general series term Φn for the stress function, from which the series expressions of the stresses and displacements may be computed for a solid shaft. In particular, the expressions of the radial displacement for a general radius and for the outer radius coincide with those reported in Barton.14

The explicit expression of Φn allows its asymptotic behaviour for high values of the series index n to be computed; the asymptotic behaviour of the shaft stresses and displacements may thus be clarified, and the corresponding series may be accelerated (Appendix 1). By employing the asymptotic expansions for the modified Bessel functions (Abramowitz and Stegun,17 p. 377), an asymptotic expression of Φn has been derived (9)Φn,asympt=-32prc3(1-rrc+4(3-2ν)πn)π2n2n(πnrrc+2) ×e-πn4(1-rrc)cos(kz) The asymptotic behaviour of the general series terms of the radial deflection for a general radius coincides with that obtained from formula (9), thus constituting a partial check on its correctness. In particular, the general series term of the normalized surface deflection behaves asymptotically as (10)uu0|asymptotic=32(1+ν)π21n2sin(kz) where u0 denotes the radial displacement for a uniform pressure equal to p/2 (formula (3)).

In Barton,14 the series expressing the radial deflection of a shaft surface loaded by contiguous, discontinuous pressure bands of intensity ±p/2 has not been accelerated, seemingly because the presence of the term 1/n2 in expression (10) guarantees a sufficiently fast convergence. However, there are several reasons that motivate the desire for a faster convergence of the above series. First, a detailed description of the shape of the shaft surface deflection requires the evaluation of the corresponding series for many axial positions; second, as a result of the series acceleration, the part of the displacement formula expressed in terms of an infinite sum exhibits a general term asymptotically behaving as sin(kz)/n3, the derivatives up to the second degree may be analytically examined for z = 0; third, the expression of the summable series constitutes the basis for the derivation of an approximate analytical expression (Appendix 2); and fourth, by differentiating the expression of the radial deflection with respect to the axial coordinate z, the deflection due to a force collar is obtained, and the series part of this expression still converges sufficiently fast as a result of the series acceleration. This last observation evidences the fact that the formulae of Appendix 2 possess an applicability field that is more general than the title problem.

In Appendix 1, a series is considered that (a) behaves asymptotically as sin(kz)/n2 and (b) is analytically summable. This series allows the series solution to be accelerated by employing the Kummer method, e.g. Strozzi,18 which consists in removing the slowly convergent part in the form of a series whose sum is expressible in a finite form.

The above relatively simple calculations valid for a solid shaft have been extended to a hollow shaft. The series expression (4) for the stress function must be employed, and two additional boundary conditions must be imposed, namely, the annulling of the radial and shear stresses at the inner border, e.g. Williams and Ranson.19 The analytical passages have been relegated to an algebraic manipulator; the formulae obtained are too complicated to be reported here. The series expression of the surface deflection of a hollow shaft may be accelerated with the same series valid for a solid shaft, since for the harmonics of high series index, the shaft radial thickness becomes non-influential. However, the series acceleration becomes practically less effective as the shaft radial thickness diminishes.

Manageable, accurate expressions have been obtained and reported in formulae (19) to (28) of Appendix 2 for the radial displacement of the cylindrical outer surface loaded by a discontinuous pressure profile formed by two adjacent bands of intensity ±p/2; see the inset of Figure 3, for ratios between the shaft inner and outer radii, ri/rc, ranging between 0 and 0.9, with step 0.1.

In the displacement formulae, the radial deflection u(z) of the shaft surface is normalized with respect to its asymptotic value u0 of formula (3), so that the corresponding expressions are not functions of the shaft outer radius rc and of the Young’s modulus Es of the shaft material, but only depend on the shaft aspect ratio ri/rc, where ri denotes the shaft bore radius, and, moderately, on the Poisson’s ratio, υ, which has been assumed to be 0.3 in formulae (20) to (28).

Figure 3 reports the normalized radial deflection of the shaft surface for the discontinuous pressure profile detailed in the inset, for a selection of ri/rc ratios, namely ri/rc = 0, 0.4, 0.8. The curves are null for z/rc = 0 and approach unity for z/rc ≅ 1.5. It is also noted that the surface radial deflection u may exceed, albeit moderately, its asymptotic value (3) before approaching it. This behaviour becomes more perceivable for high values of the ri/rc ratio. As an example, point A in Figure 3 indicates the beginning of the diminution of the radial deflection towards its asymptotic value for the curve referring to ri/rc = 0.8.

The expression of the radial thickness, t, of the material to be removed from the cylindrical hub bore to get a uniform contact pressure must become null at the hub centre. Consequently, the expression of t(z), where z is an axial coordinate whose origin coincides with a hub lateral side and points to the hub centre, is obtained from the expression (11)t(z)=[1-u(z)u0]u0 where the constant u0 is expressed by formula (3), whereas u(z)/u0 is quantified by formulae (19) to (28) for a selection of ri/rc values. In particular, the radial thickness t of the hub bore material to be removed at the hub sides (z = 0) is exactly expressed by formula (3), which in fact coincides with formula (11) when z = 0. In addition, the radial thickness t becomes essentially zero at an axial distance from the hub bore sides of about 1.5 rc (see Figure 3 and the comments in ‘Radial deflection of the shaft surface’ section).

Although the three curves of Figure 3 are reasonably similar, the finite element (FE) forecasts show that only the curve referring to the actual ri/rc ratio returns an essentially uniform contact pressure. The FE forecasts clarify that the part of the profile that mainly dictates the shape of the contact pressure is the steep gradient zone. This observation suggests two alternative, approximate approaches.

First, since the curve referring to ri/rc = 0 exhibits the steepest initial part with respect to higher values of the ri/rc aspect ratio, it may be employed instead of the curve addressing the actual value of ri/rc; the resulting pressure profile will not remain perfectly constant, but it will become null at the shaft–hub contact extremities, without being affected by undesired lateral pressure spikes. This finding has been assessed with selected FE studies.

The second approximate approach is discussed as follows. The curves of Appendix 2, reporting the shaft radial displacement, are presented for a selection of ri/rc values. If the ri/rc value of the shaft to be considered is, say, 0.55, the corresponding radial displacement may be derived from the formulae of ‘Peculiarities of the mechanical response of the shaft–hub contact’ section in two possible ways: (a) by carrying out a linear interpolation and (b) by referring to the closest ri/rc value, considered in Appendix 2, lower than the actual value, i.e. 0.5. This second approximation is justified by the above FE results.

Some additional methods unsuccessfully employed to forecast the radial deflection of the shaft surface are perfunctorily mentioned as follows. First, the thin-walled cylinder solution of Timoshenko and Woinowsky-Krieger20 (p. 466) cannot model the steep initial gradient of the radial deflection of the shaft outer surface. FE forecasts show that a hub bore profile based on the thin-walled cylinder solution fails to return a uniform contact pressure, since undesired pressure spikes affect the contact extremities. The perturbation solution of e.g. Strozzi,21 suitable for modelling cylindrical problems and successfully employed in biomechanical problems, has been found to suffer from similar limitations. Finally, a series solution cast in terms of Legendre polynomials, for which explicit expressions of the series terms have recently been obtained in Strozzi,22 was found to be unsuitable for this application, since the Heaviside function hardly lends itself to be thoroughly described in terms of polynomials along a sizeable interval (see Figure 1 of Calders and Jaroszewicz23). However, the solution in terms of Legendre polynomials has been found to be useful to retrieve some preliminary indications on the effects of some shape errors on the pressure profile (‘Effect of some shape errors’ section).

sec.title: Hubs of limited axial length
sec.p: To avoid confusion, axially short hubs have not been considered in the previous sections; they are specifically addressed in this section.

It has been emphasized in ‘Radial deflection of the shaft surface’ section that the radial deflection of a shaft loaded by a Heaviside pressure profile essentially reaches its asymptotic value at a distance of about 1.5 times the shaft outer radius. Consequently, for hubs whose axial length is higher than 1.5 × 2 = 3 times the shaft outer radius, no interaction occurs between the two transition zones at the two extremities of the shaft–hub contact, each describing the radial deflection of the shaft outer surface between the points B and C of Figure 1. Consequently, the approach presented in ‘Peculiarities of the mechanical response of the shaft–hub contact’ section to achieve a uniform contact pressure is confidently applicable. Conversely, when dealing with axially shorter hubs, frequently encountered in the engineering practice, the approach favoured in this article must be corrected to account for the mutual interactions between the shaft deformations at the two shaft–hub contact extremities.

In what follows, two pressure profiles are considered (a) a pressure band of intensity p, whose axial length is finite and coincides with the hub length and (b) a discontinuous pressure profile constituted by two adjacent, infinitely long pressure bands of intensity ±p/2 (see the inset of Figure 3). To account for the mutual interactions between the shaft deformations at the two shaft–hub contact extremities, it is necessary to determine the surface radial deflection of an infinitely long shaft subjected to the pressure profile (a); following Figure 218 of Timoshenko and Goodier,16 the above pressure profile (a) may be obtained by superposing two pressure profiles (b), axially shifted by a length equal to that of the hub. Consequently, the expression of the radial thickness, t, of the material to be removed from the hub bore lateral zones to get a uniform contact pressure is expressed by the following modification of formula (11) (details are omitted for brevity) (12)t(z)=[2-u(z)u0-u(l-z)u0]u0 where z is an axial coordinate whose origin coincides with a hub lateral side and points to the hub centre, l the hub axial length and u(z)/u0 expressed by formulae (19) to (28). The FE forecasts confirm that for hubs of axial length l for which l/rc > 3, formula (11) is applicable, see the first example of the following section; for shorter hubs, formula (12) must be used, see the second example of the same section.

sec.title: Selected examples
sec.p: Some practical examples, partially extracted from Strozzi et al.,6 are presented in detail in this section, aimed at allowing the non-specialist to correctly employ the proposed design procedure without excessively dwelling on the underlying theoretical aspects. It is recalled that ri, rc and ro denote the shaft inner radius, the shaft outer radius (which nominally coincides with the hub inner radius) and the hub outer radius, respectively. In addition, l is the hub axial length, Es and Eh the shaft and hub Young’s moduli, respectively, and υ the Poisson’s ratio.

In the first example, the nominal geometry of the shaft and the hub is defined by the following values: ri = 0 mm, rc = 16 mm, ro = 40 mm and l = 60 mm. The Young’s modulus for the shaft and the hub is 210,000 MPa and υ = 0.3. The torque T to be transmitted is 8000 Nm, and the estimated coefficient of friction is 0.2.

From formula (2) connecting the transmissible torque to the contact pressure, the contact pressure must be 414.47 MPa. (The Mohr equivalent stress for the hub is 2 × 414.47/[1–(16/40)2] = 986.83 MPa.) From formula (1) connecting the interference to the contact pressure, the diametral interference I must be 0.1504 mm. If the shaft outer radius is 16 mm, the hub bore radius must be rc − I/2 = 16–0.1504/2 = 15.9248 mm. This radius describes the perfectly cylindrical central part of the hub bore. This example confirms the fact that formula (1) is the only mathematical passage in which the hub outer radius, ro, and the Young’s modulus of the hub material, Eh, intervene.

To achieve a uniform contact pressure, some material must be radially removed along the bore lateral portions with respect to the above perfectly cylindrical bore shape. Since the hub axial length is higher than three times the shaft outer radius, l > 3rc, the radial depth t(z) of the material to be removed from the lateral zones of the hub bore is correctly quantified by formula (11), where the origin of the z-coordinate coincides with one of the hub lateral sides, and it points to the hub centre. In particular, the material to be radially removed from the sides (i.e. z = 0) of the hub bore (whose radius is 15.9248 mm) is 0.0111 mm; the radial removal of hub material must be effected along two axial portions starting from the two hub sides and of length about 1.5rc; a profile whose vertical value starts from 0.0111 mm and becomes essentially zero at an axial distance of about 1.5 rc = 24 mm is not too dissimilar from the profiles employed in precision mechanics examined in ‘Introduction’; they are deemed to be accurately machinable with CNC and multi-axis control. The normally achievable tolerance range is in the region of ±4 µm, which generally implies that the machined profile is very close to that requested, although it is possibly shifted by a few micrometres and/or rotated by a small amount. The effect of simple shape errors is discussed in ‘Effect of some shape errors’ section.

As already observed, at the hub sides, z = 0, the radial depth to be removed from the hub bore is 0.0111 mm; for z = rc/16 = 1 mm, the radial depth becomes 0.0077 mm; for z = rc/8 = 2 mm, the radial depth diminishes to 0.0053 mm, and it is about half the value referring to z = 0; for z = rc/4 = 4 mm, the radial depth becomes 0.0026 mm. (For clarity, the final bore profile is mathematically obtained by modifying a perfectly cylindrical bore. However, when machining the final bore profile, there is no need to machine a perfectly cylindrical bore first.)

Since expressions (19) to (28) employed to shape the hub bore are approximate, the hub bore edges might (slightly) indent the shaft, thus producing undesired lateral pressure peaks and local yielding. It is therefore convenient to adopt a diametral interference I slightly lower than its analytical value, say 0.95 I (the amount of this diminution might be correlated to the tolerance range achieved, see ‘Conclusions’ section), and remove the hub material according to expression (6) in which u0 is computed from the value of the pressure p promoted by the original interference. As a result of both this adaptation and the approximation illustrated in Figure 2, the contact pressure is expected to become null at the contact extremities and, possibly, to become moderately camel backed; its central value will be 0.95 times that promoted by the original interference.

A hub with diametral interference I = 0.95 × 0.1504 = 0.1429 mm, (consequently, the shaft outer radius is 16 mm and the hub bore radius is 16–0.1429/2 = 15.9286 mm), whose bore axial profile has been shaped according to equation (11) and press-fitted onto a shaft, has been modelled with FE, and the corresponding pressure profile is presented in Figure 4. The pressure, normalized over the central pressure p0, that is, over the pressure value obtained with the plane model of formula (1) and referring to the actual interference, remains substantially uniform along most of the contact zone without exhibiting a camel-backed profile, and it becomes null along a very narrow interval in the vicinity of the contact extremities (in Figure 4, only the x-axis zone defined by z/rc < 0.1 is represented). The circumstance that the contact pressure remains virtually uniform implies that the approximation discussed in Figure 2, consisting of neglecting the axial displacements of the contacting surfaces, is fully acceptable.

It was observed in ‘Introduction’ that, if the shaft–hub mating profiles produce a uniform contact pressure, the elastically transmissible torque attains its maximum value. It may additionally be noted that, if a uniform pressure is attained, the elastically transmissible torque may become several times higher than that achievable by rounding the hub bore edges according to engineering practice (see Strozzi et al.6) and this result may justify the employment in precision mechanics applications of the refined shaping of the hub bore presented in this article.

In the second example, the geometry of the shaft and the hub is defined by the following values: ri = 6 mm, rc = 12 mm, ro = 22 mm and l = 6 mm. (It is noted that l ≪ 3rc. A considerably short hub has been employed to evidence the difference with respect to an axially long hub.) The Young’s modulus for the shaft and the hub is 210,000 MPa and υ = 0.3. The torque T to be transmitted is 600 Nm, and the estimated coefficient of friction is 0.25.

From formula (2), the contact pressure must be 442.10 MPa. (The Mohr equivalent stress for the hub is 2 × 442.10/[1 − (12/22)2] = 1258.68 MPa.). From formula (1), the diametral interference I must be 0.1775 mm. The material to be radially removed from the sides of the hub bore (i.e. z = 0) is computed from formula (12), obtaining t(z = 0) = 0.0191 mm. This value is perceivably higher than that valid for an axially long hub, computed from formula (11), t(z = 0) = 0.0173 mm. The material to be removed from the hub bore centre is t(z = l/2) = 0.0130 mm, and it is not null, as in long hubs. The above result may be rationalized by noting that a band of fixed pressure p produces a shaft radial deflection that decreases as the band axial length decreases. Consequently, the shaft–hub interference must be lowered with respect to the plane stress interference derived from formula (1) or with respect to a long hub, and this requires that a higher radial thickness of the material be removed along the whole hub inner border, i.e. both at the sides and the contact centre.

A hub with diametral interference I = 0.95 × 0.1775 = 0.1686 mm, (consequently, the shaft outer radius is 12 mm and the hub bore radius 12–0.1405/2 = 11.9157 mm), whose bore axial profile has been shaped according to equation (12) in which u0 is computed from the value of the pressure p promoted by the original interference, has been modelled with FE, and the corresponding pressure profile is presented in Figure 5. The contact pressure has been normalized over the pressure value p0 obtained with the plane model of formula (1) and referring to the actual interference. The pressure remains essentially uniform along most of the contact length, and it becomes null at the contact extremities. Figure 5.
The pressure profile for the second example.

sec.title: Effect of some shape errors
sec.p: In CNC machining, the profile to be obtained is normally described in terms of a spline. The consequences on the contact pressure of a spline interpolation of the analytical profiles of Appendix 2 have been numerically explored by referring to the first example of ‘Selected examples’ section. Two cubic spline interpolations have been considered; in the first interpolation, the knots are equidistant along the z-axis, with a step of 0.01 mm; in the second interpolation, the z-coordinates of the first four knots are 0, 0.01, 0.05 and 0.1 mm, whereas the step of the following knots remains constantly as 0.1 mm. In both interpolations, no condition is imposed on the spline slope at the first knot, whereas continuity of first and second derivatives is imposed at the second knot. For the remaining knots, continuity of the function and its first derivative is imposed, as usual.

Figure 6 displays the two contact pressure profiles, referring to uniformly spaced knots and to knots accumulated in the vicinity of the contact extremity, respectively. Apart from a localized, moderate ripple affecting the curve with variable step and confidently imputable to the abrupt step variation, the two profiles are very similar. This numerical result confirms the observation made at the end of ‘The Barton series solution reconsidered’ section, according to which the part of the profile that mainly dictates the shape of the contact pressure is the steep gradient zone. Figure 6.
Two contact pressure profiles for spline interpolations.

The following analysis addresses the effect on the pressure distribution of some simple shape errors of the hub bore profile in the axial direction, due to machining errors. It has already been noted that in high-tech applications, the normally achievable tolerance range of CNC falls in the region of ±4 µm. This piece of information simply guarantees that the actual profile falls within the above interval; however, the engineering practice additionally suggests that the actual profile be sufficiently regular and that diffused ripples are rarely encountered.

In fact, a major error source is the increase in temperature due to the progression in machining; the corresponding dilatation will generally act smoothly, thus producing equally smooth errors of the actual profile.

With the above premises in mind, it was decided to explore the effects of two simple shape errors, namely a linear and a quadratic. (A rigid radial translation has not been investigated, since it is equivalent to a simple variation in the interference value.) The linear error may be interpreted as a rigid rotation of the hub bore profile that returns a uniform pressure, and it has been numerically explored by referring to the first example of ‘Selected examples’ section, and to an imposed interference of 0.95 I. Only one half of the contact profile is considered, and the original profile is rigidly rotated in two distinct ways; in the first way, the midpoint of the profile is moved centripetally by 4 µm, whereas the profile extremity is moved centrifugally by 4 µm (this profile will be referred to as ‘conical inverse barrelled’); in the second way, the midpoint of the profile is moved centrifugally by 4 µm, whereas the profile extremity is moved centripetally by 4 µm (this profile will be referred to as ‘conical barrelled’). (More exactly, the y-coordinate is modified linearly, whereas the x-coordinate is not altered. The profiles are directly derived from the expressions of Appendix 2, and spline interpolations are not used in this investigation.)

The two corresponding pressure profiles activated by the biconical contact profiles are illustrated in Figure 7. The conical inverse barrelled profile does not produce any extremity indentation between the hub bore edge and the shaft, and the contact pressure becomes smoothly null at the contact end. Conversely, the conical barrelled profile causes an extremity indentation, which promotes an infinite pressure peak at the contact end. The third curve of Figure 7 addresses a conical barrelled profile whose interference has been lowered from 0.95 I to 0.9 I. In this case, no indentation occurs, and the contact pressure is null at the contact extremity (see Figure 7, curve labelled 0.9 I). Figure 7.
Contact pressure profiles for linear errors.

The part of the pressure profile far from the contact extremity is essentially linear, apart from a cusp at the contact centre, due to the biconical shape of the hub profile. This example evidences that once the analytical value for the interference is computed from equation (1), the value to be adopted in practical applications must be reduced according to the expected shape error of the profile. It is however difficult to derive a practical rule suggesting which reduction of the initial interference may preclude any undesired extremity indentation.

The analytical solution of the cylindrical problem in terms of Legendre polynomials (see Strozzi22) provides an indication regarding the effect of a conical shape error describable as a rigid rotation on the almost linear part of the contact profile. This solution shows that if the radial displacement ur at the surface of an infinitely long, possibly hollow, cylinder varies linearly in the axial direction, then the surface radial stress σr varies linearly according to a Winkler model (the shear stress τrz is identically null). For instance, for a solid shaft, if ur = Cz, where z is the axial coordinate, then σr = CEz/[rc(1 − υ)]. It may be concluded that formula (1), expressing the press-fit pressure between a shaft and a hub as a function of the interference, is exactly applicable to infinitely long shafts and hubs, in which the interference varies linearly in the shaft axial direction.

By referring to the geometry of the first example of ‘Selected examples’ section, and by employing the above expressions of ur and σr, the absolute value of the slope of the linear portion of the normalized pressure curve versus the normalized z-coordinate should analytically be about 0.06. For the two curves referring to an interference of 0.95 I, Figure 7 suggests a reasonably similar absolute value of the numerical slopes of about 0.074.

Finally, the effect has been numerically explored of shape errors of the hub bore profile that returns a uniform pressure, describable as quadratic curves with null tangent at the contact axial midpoint. The analytical solution in terms of Legendre polynomials shows that for quadratic shape errors, the pressure varies quadratically, although it does no longer adhere to a Winkler model.

Reference has again been made to the first example of ‘Selected examples’ section, and to an imposed interference of 0.95 I. Two quadratic errors are considered; the first error is described by a quadratic curve whose midpoint is moved centripetally by 4 µm, whereas the curve extremities are moved centrifugally by 4 µm, referred to as ‘inverse barrelled’; the second error is described by a quadratic curve whose midpoint is moved centrifugally by 4 µm, whereas the curve extremities are moved centripetally by 4 µm, referred to as ‘barrelled’.

The two corresponding numerical pressure profiles are shown in Figure 8. The inverse barrelled profile does not produce any extremity indentation between the hub bore edge and the shaft, and the contact pressure becomes smoothly null at the contact extremity. Conversely, the barrelled profile produces an infinite pressure peak at the contact end. The third curve of Figure 8 refers to a barrelled profile whose interference has been lowered from 0.95 I to 0.9 I. In this case, the contact pressure does not become infinite at the contact extremity (see Figure 8, curve labelled 0.9 I). Figure 8.
Contact pressure profiles for quadratic errors.

From Figure 8, it appears that the portion of the normalized numerical pressure curve sufficiently far from the contact extremity may be approximated by a quadratic curve, in agreement with the analytical solution based upon Legendre polynomials.

The uncertainty, due to tolerances, in the shape of the contacting profiles may produce significant deviations from the optimal profile that cannot be described by simple linear or quadratic curves, examined above. It is difficult to explore the consequence on the pressure profile of an error of general shape. In fact, general shape errors may return an appreciably non-uniform contact pressure, and problems in which the contact pressure is deemed not to remain constant may not be examined with the approach favoured in this article, in which the pressure is assumed to stay essentially constant. A FE investigation would therefore become necessary for every specific problem to forecast the deviations of the pressure profile from the uniform distribution as a result of the approximations in the machining of the mating profiles. The selection of the tolerance range and a thorough analysis of its influence on the pressure profile are therefore problems that fall outside the scope of this paper.

Another aspect not thoroughly examined in this article is the influence of the coefficient of friction and, in particular, the effect of the shear stresses τrz and τrθ acting at the mating surfaces. It may be noted that in shrink-fitted couplings, the shear stresses τrz, acting along the contact surface and caused by the differential axial deformations, produce an inverse barrelled deformation of the hub, which releases the peak stresses at the contact extremities. Consequently, if the contact pressure computed by ignoring the frictional effects does not exhibit endpoint pressure spikes, the introduction of friction will not generally favour the outcome of endpoint pressure peaks. Conversely, in press-fitted couplings, the direction of the shear stresses along the contact surface depends upon the press-fit procedures, and it is often undefined;6 consequently, rules of general validity are not available. Moving to the shear stresses τrθ acting along the contact surface and connected to the torque transmission, they are deemed not to modify the contact pressure referring to a frictionless contact, as they alter the angles and not the radial lengths.6 The authors of this article are grateful to an anonymous reviewer for signalling Dundurs and Comninou,24 presenting elastic solutions for a plane contact problem with friction.

As a final remark, the approach favoured in this article is applicable provided the hub cross section is rectangular and, consequently, the shaft is cylindrical. In the hip replacement field, with reference to the contact between the stem and the head cavity, the ‘hub’ cross section is no longer rectangular and the stem is conical, e.g. Fessler and Fricker.25 The approach of this article is therefore not strictly applicable, but it may still suggest a preliminary profile of the mating surfaces, returning a contact pressure profile with no pressure spikes and with reduced lateral pressure bumps.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The achievement of a uniform elastic contact pressure in a frictionless, keyless, shaft–hub interference fit obtained by properly shaping the mating profiles has been examined. The peculiarity of the hub mechanical response according to which, under the effect of a uniform pressure applied to the hub bore, the bore axial profile moves radially without any distortion has been exploited to simplify the determination of the mating profiles that return a uniform pressure. In particular, it has been shown that the hub radial deflection may be computed with a simple plane model, whereas only the shaft radial deflection requires a more complex analysis in cylindrical coordinates. Explicit approximate expressions have been reported for the shapes to be conferred to the mating profiles to achieve a uniform pressure. Selected examples have been presented to clarify the proposed design procedure and to explore the effect on the pressure profile of linear and quadratic shape errors.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Appendix 1
sec.p: An acceleration of the convergence of the original series of Barton14 expressing the radial displacements of the solid shaft surface as well as of the extension of the above study to hollow shafts (‘The Barton series solution reconsidered’ section) is achieved here by resorting to the Kummer method, e.g. Strozzi.18 In what follows, a series is obtained that (a) behaves asymptotically as sin(nπz/(4rc))/n2 and (b) is analytically summable. The computations carried out to achieve the above series are presented in some detail below, since the analytical evaluation of a series involving only odd indices is less commonly encountered than its full integer index counterpart.

Staring from the classical geometric series sum (13)∑k=1,2,3∞zk=11-z and by performing the change of index (14)n=2k+1; k=n-12 the geometric series becomes (15)∑n=1,3,5∞zn-12=11-z By setting (16)q=z the above series becomes (17)∑n=1,3,5∞qn-1=11-q2 which is similar to the original geometric series (13), but in which only odd indices are involved. The remaining passages developed to derive the required series sum are standard, and only a perfunctory account of them is reported here. By multiplying both members of equation (17) by q, integrating twice with respect to q, setting q = cosθ + i sinθ and extracting the imaginary part from both members, the required analytical expression of the series sum is obtained (18)∑n=1,3,5∞sin[(n+2)θ](n+1)(n+2) =14[-2sinθlog(2sinθ)+4sinθ +2(π2-θ)cosθ-π] 0≤θ≤π For negative θ angles, the above series may be evaluated by exploiting its skew-symmetric behaviour.

The above series is adapted to the displacement formula of Barton14 by putting θ = πz/(4rc). The general term of the above series behaves as sin(nπz/(4rc))/n2 for high values of the series index n, as required.

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p: The following formulae describe the radial displacement u of the outer surface of a possibly hollow shaft, loaded by a Heaviside band of pressure in which the pressure jump is p. Each formula is valid for a specific ratio ri/rc, where ri and rc denote the shaft inner and outer radii, respectively. Formulae for ri/rc, ranging from 0 to 0.9 with a step of unity have been obtained. The origin of the axial coordinate z coincides with the pressure jump. The radial u is normalized with respect to the radial displacement of the solid cylinder surface for a uniform pressure equal to p/2, i.e. it represents the radial displacement far away from the pressure discontinuity (formula (3)).
The u/u0 formulae presented hold for 0 ≤ z/rc ≤ 2; for z/rc > 2, the u/u0 expressions should be assumed as equal to unity.

For ri/rc = 0, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (19)u(z)u0=8(1+ν)π2{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +8(1+ν)π{1(2ν+2.00735)sin(πz4rc) +[16ν+7.08009-0.21221]sin(3πz4rc) +[11 0ν+16.9889-0.06366]sin(5πz4rc) +[11 4ν+33.4514-0.03032]sin(7πz4rc) +[11 8ν+56.416-0.01768]sin(9πz4rc)}

It is noted that in formula (19), the function sin[πz/(4rc)] appears twice. It was decided to not unify such components in a single term to conform to the technique employed for obtaining this expression and producing an accelerated part and a series one.

For ri/rc = 0.1, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (20)u(z)u0=1.02418{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.26940sin(πz4rc)-0.31336sin(3πz4rc) -0.04295sin(5πz4rc)-0.0120019sin(7πz4rc) -0.00484069sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.2, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (21)u(z)u0=0.941640{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.26885sin(πz4rc)-0.266775sin(3πz4rc) -0.036341sin(5πz4rc)-0.0106873sin(7πz4rc) -0.00441613sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.3, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (22)u(z)u0=0.82158{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.26832sin(πz4rc)-0.196674sin(3πz4rc) -0.025429sin(5πz4rc)-0.0084362sin(7πz4rc) -0.00373582sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.4, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (23)u(z)u0=0.6823781{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.2681452sin(πz4rc)-0.1111387sin(3πz4rc) -0.01026174sin(5πz4rc)-0.00505955 ×sin(7πz4rc)-0.00276363sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.5, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (24)u(z)u0=0.5397206{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.2685032sin(πz4rc)-0.01697868 ×sin(3πz4rc)+0.0095867sin(5πz4rc) -0.0000986sin(7πz4rc) -0.00131163sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.6, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (25)u(z)u0=0.40417437{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.26937726sin(πz4rc)+0.08115869 ×sin(3πz4rc)+0.03561610sin(5πz4rc) +0.0074039sin(7πz4rc) +0.00108498sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.7, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (26)u(z)u0=0.28136521{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.27058743sin(πz4rc)+0.18000773 ×sin(3πz4rc)+0.07143691sin(5πz4rc) +0.0196525sin(7πz4rc) +0.00546841sin(9πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.8, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (27)u(z)u0=0.1733307{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.271851sin(πz4rc)+0.275613 ×sin(3πz4rc)+0.124012sin(5πz4rc) +0.0430594sin(7πz4rc) +0.0149330sin(9πz4rc)+0.0056410 ×sin(11πz4rc)+0.0023100sin(13πz4rc) For ri/rc = 0.9, the normalized approximate analytical expression of the normalized radial displacement of the surface of the solid cylinder is (28)u(z)u0=0.0799472{-2sin(πz4rc)log[2sin(πz4rc)] +4sin(πz4rc)+2[π2-(πz4rc)]cos(πz4rc)-π} +1.272842sin(πz4rc)+0.360752 ×sin(3πz4rc)+0.198125sin(5πz4rc) +0.0990273sin(7πz4rc) +0.0451744sin(9πz4rc)+0.0205996 ×sin(11πz4rc)+0.0099049sin(13πz4rc) The series solution for a hollow shaft is considerably more complex than its counterpart for a solid shaft. As a consequence, in the approximate analytical expressions (19) to (28), addressing solid and variously bored shafts, it was possible to evidence the effect of the Poisson’s ratio only for a solid shaft (expression (19)), whereas the remaining expressions, dealing with hollow shafts, are valid only for υ = 3.

The relative error of formulae (19) to (27) with respect to the series predictions of Barton14 stands well below 1% for 0.15 < z/rc < 2. The error of formula (28) is about 2%, since the Kummer method is less effective, as discussed at the end of ‘The Barton series solution reconsidered’ section. (The zone of high displacement slope defined by z/rc < 0.15 has not been considered in the evaluation of the relative error. However, a high number of digits has been employed in formulae (19) to (28) to limit the error in the steep gradient zone, since this part of the profile mainly dictates the shape of the contact pressure, see ‘Effect of some shape errors’ section.)

Expressions of the shaft axial deformation have not been reported, since in this article, it was decided to adopt the simplification according to which the axial deformations are neglected (see Figure 2 and the related comments).
